awd_titl_txt: Science and Mathematics Attraction, Retention, and Training for Texas (SMART Texas)
awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project at Stephen F. Austin State University (SFASU) will provide academic, social, career preparation, and scholarship support to approximately twenty (20) financially deserving mathematics and biology majors with high academic potential. The goals of the Science and Mathematics Attraction, Retention, and Training for Texas (SMART Texas) program are to: (1) increase the number of students entering and completing a mathematics or biology major; (2) prepare  mathematics and biology majors for the workforce or graduate study; and (3) investigate and identify key elements of a replicable model for STEM student success with a special focus on first generation low-income and other underrepresented groups of undergraduate students.

This SMART Texas project will incorporate a combination of innovative and established best practice strategies to increase recruitment and retention, as well as improve student success and graduation rates. The scholarship students will engage in a STEM living learning community where they will be involved with STEM peers and STEM faculty in both academic and non-academic settings. S-STEM students will have access to cohort mentoring, dedicated academic mentoring by faculty in their discipline, internships and undergraduate research opportunities (including laboratory research), and a variety of networking opportunities including support to attend and participate in  discipline conferences.  The planned combination of strategies will be implemented and investigated to determine obstacles students face and best practices to help overcome these obstacles to increase participation, retention, graduation, and overall student success, especially for underrepresented groups. A paired longitudinal study will be conducted to examine the effects of these interventions over time when compared to nonparticipating STEM majors. Results will be disseminated throughout the STEM community.

por.por_cntn:
From 2015 to 2021, the project entitled Science and Mathematics Attraction, Retention, and Training for Texas (SMART Texas) directly supported 30 Mathematics and Biology students with scholarships, mentoring, STEM community engagement opportunities, and STEM research exposure.  By design, the STEM support communities developed for these scholars also supported over 100 additional STEM majors who did not receive the scholarship.

The project began by recruiting a cohort of diverse STEM students. Once the students were on campus, they were immediately folded into an active STEM community and each was assigned a STEM faculty advisor who met with and mentored them. A STEM residential learning community was created to support these scholars and use the scholars as a nucleus to connect a larger group of STEM majors in authentic academic community. A similar strategy was employed in the creation of a 1-credit-hour STEM first-year success course – again including scholars and other STEM majors. Finally, project personnel designed a variety of STEM fieldtrips which were tailored to the interests of the STEM scholars and local STEM industry, then included as many STEM students as possible.

SMART Texas scholars were actively encouraged to attend academic conferences. They were also actively exposed to undergraduate research opportunities and placed into informal social settings with STEM faculty where research and career trajectories were discussed.

The graduation rates of these students were 30% higher than a paired comparison group in the same majors. Program participants also had dramatically higher participation in academic clubs (76% vs. 24%), STEM fieldtrips (88% vs. 12%), academic conference attendance (88% vs. 12%), undergraduate research (91% vs. 9%), and STEM internships (57% vs. 43%). Findings related to the project have been disseminated through two academic articles and nine conference presentations.

 


Last Modified: 12/07/2021
Modified by: Keith Hubbard
